slides.title: What Is a 15‑Minute City?

content.definition: A planning framework that clusters daily needs—home, work, learning, care, groceries, parks—within a 15‑minute walk or bike ride, prioritizing proximity, safety, and choice.
principles: Diversity: mixed uses and housing types
Density done well: enough people to support services
Human‑scaled streets: slower speeds, greener public realm
Digital/physical integration: delivery lockers, telehealth, coworking
Equity: invest first where access gaps are largest
Climate resilience: shade, stormwater, low‑carbon mobility

slides.title: Case Studies: Paris & Melbourne

paris.approach: Citywide proximity strategy—school street closures, bike network expansion, local services, and 30 km/h default on most streets.
paris.learning: Pair quick‑build trials with permanent upgrades; communicate benefits at the block level.

melbourne.approach: ‘20‑minute neighborhoods’ within Plan Melbourne (walkable catchments to daily needs).
melbourne.learning: Use activity center hierarchy to stage investment; align with health outcomes.

slides.title: Street Redesign Elements (Complete Streets)

elements: Continuous sidewalks with curb ramps and tactile paving
Protected bike lanes (physical separation) and intersection protection
Bus priority (dedicated lanes, queue jumps), all‑door boarding
Traffic calming: 30 km/h design speeds, raised crossings, chicanes
Curb management: loading bays, micromobility parking, parklets
Green infrastructure: shade trees, bioswales, permeable surfaces

General traffic lane: 2.7 m each direction
cross_section_spec.notes: Adjust widths to local standards; maintain continuous protection at intersections.

slides.title: Mixed‑Use Zoning Toolkit

tools.name: Form‑Based Codes
tools.purpose: Regulate form and frontage, not just use; ensure active ground floors.

tools.name: Missing‑Middle Housing
tools.purpose: Triplexes, courtyard apts, ADUs to diversify options near services.

tools.name: Adaptive Reuse
tools.purpose: Convert offices/big‑box to housing, schools, clinics.

tools.name: Parking Reform
tools.purpose: Eliminate minimums; use maximums/shared/cash‑out; price curbs.

tools.name: Inclusionary Zoning
tools.purpose: Reserve % of units as affordable near transit/amenities.

tools.name: Corner Commercial Allowance
tools.purpose: Small‑format retail/childcare/cafés embedded in residential blocks.

content.policy_note: Pair zoning with grants/TA for small developers and main‑street businesses.

slides.title: Mobility Modes & Networks

modes: Walking: universal baseline; continuous shade and crossings
Cycling/e‑bikes: protected network; secure parking at shops/schools
Transit: frequent local buses/trams; timed transfers; integrated fares
Micromobility: shared scooters/bikes with designated corrals
Deliveries: cargo bikes and off‑peak loading to reduce conflicts
Car share: right‑sized auto access without ownership

slides.title: Equity & Accessibility

equity_levers: Invest first in underserved neighborhoods (access deserts).
Zero‑fare/transit discounts for low‑income riders and youth.
Anti‑displacement: community land trusts, right‑to‑return, rent stabilization tools.
Safe routes to school and late‑night worker corridors.
Community co‑design: multilingual workshops, stipends, childcare.
universal_design: Continuous curb ramps and tactile guidance at crossings.
Audible signals; seating every 100–150 m; shade and lighting.
Step‑free building entries; wider doorways; at‑grade transit boarding.

map_spec.metric: Access Index (share of households within 15‑min walk to 5+ services)
map_spec.overlay: Transit frequency and crash hot spots (heat points)
map_spec.classification: quintiles; darkest = lowest access; outline priority areas

slides.title: Misconceptions & Myth‑Busting
content: Myth: 15‑minute cities ‘restrict movement.’ → Fact: They expand choices by bringing more nearby; regional and intercity travel remains.
Myth: It’s anti‑car. → Fact: It’s pro‑option; safer walking/biking/transit plus smarter car use.
Myth: Only works in dense European cores. → Fact: Applicable with context—retrofit arterials, re‑center town centers, and add mixed uses.
Myth: Hurts business. → Fact: Foot traffic and dwell time typically increase on people‑first streets.
Myth: Too expensive. → Fact: Low‑cost pilots and curb pricing fund phased, high‑return upgrades.
Myth: One‑size‑fits‑all. → Fact: Co‑designed with neighborhoods; services reflect local needs.

slides.title: Implementation Roadmap & Metrics Dashboard

0–6 months: Choose 2–3 pilot neighborhoods via equity criteria.
Quick‑build: school streets, pop‑up bikeways, curb management zones.
Launch co‑design workshops; publish access baseline and targets.
6–18 months: Make successful pilots permanent; shade trees and drainage added.
Zoning updates: missing‑middle, corner retail, parking reform.
Transit: signal priority, bus lanes on key corridors.
18–36 months: Scale to additional districts; integrate health and economic KPIs.
Institutionalize curb pricing; fund maintenance and main‑street grants.
Annual report with isochrone maps and crash/health outcomes.
